title: 108_hr4915
content: The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It introduces an exclusion for gain from stock of small, publicly traded companies in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" excludes gain from the sale or exchange of section 1203 stock held for more than 1 year for taxpayers other than corporations. The exclusion is limited to $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately) per taxable year. 1203 stock refers to stock in a qualified small business C corporation acquired after the enactment of the Act. The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" excludes gain from the sale or exchange of section 1203 stock held for more than 1 year for taxpayers other than corporations. The exclusion is limited to $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately) per taxable year. 1203 stock refers to stock in a qualified small business C corporation acquired after the enactment of the Act. The qualified small business is defined as a domestic C corporation with a market capitalization not exceeding $150,000,000 at the time of stock acquisition. The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" excludes gain from the sale or exchange of section 1203 stock held for more than 1 year for taxpayers other than corporations. The exclusion is limited to $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately) per taxable year. Market capitalization of a qualified small business C corporation must not exceed $150,000,000 at the time of stock acquisition for the exclusion to apply. The reporting period for determining the exclusion of gain from the sale of section 1203 stock is based on the most recent annual or quarterly report filed with the SEC. Aggregation rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply for determining the exclusion. Additional rules in subsections (f), (g), (h), (i), and (j) also apply for this purpose. The rules for determining the exclusion of gain from the sale of section 1203 stock are based on the most recent SEC report. Aggregation rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply, and additional rules from subsections (f), (g), (h), (i), and (j) also apply. Conforming amendments are made to sections 642(c)(4) and 643(a)(3) of the Code. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including inserting references to section 1203 in addition to 1202. A new subsection is added to section 1202 regarding sales and exchanges under section 1203. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. The amendments made by this section apply to securities acquired after the enactment of this Act.
